com.centurylink.mdw.activity.types

Interface SuspendableActivity

  • All Superinterfaces:
    ActivityCategory, Category
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    DependenciesWaitActivity, EventWaitActivity, InvokeProcessActivity, OrchestratorActivity, PauseActivity, SuspendibleActivity, SynchronizationActivity
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractWait, AutoFormManualTaskActivity, CustomManualTaskActivity, DependenciesWaitActivity, EventCheckActivity, EventWaitActivity, InvokeHeterogeneousProcessActivity, InvokeProcessActivityBase, InvokeSubProcessActivity, ManualTaskActivity, OrchestratorActivity, PauseActivity, SynchronizationActivity, TimerWaitActivity

    public interface SuspendableActivity
extends ActivityCategory
    This interface must be implemented by all activities that is suspendible (may be put in WAITING status). This includes timer wait, event wait, synchronization, process invocation, synchronous JMS/MQ adapters, and manual tasks. The activity will be resumed from some external event and the engine will invoke the resume() method defined here.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean needSuspend()
      The method is invoked by the engine right after the activity is executed, to determine whether to put the activity instance in waiting status.
      boolean resume(InternalEvent eventMessageDoc)
      The method is invoked when the wait activity is resumed.
      boolean resumeWaiting(InternalEvent event)
      The method is invoked when the wait activity was put on hold status (due to time out for event wait activities, or receiving non-task events for manual task activities).

    • Method Detail

      • needSuspend

        boolean needSuspend()
             throws ActivityException
        The method is invoked by the engine right after the activity is executed, to determine whether to put the activity instance in waiting status. Not all suspendible activities need to be suspended. For example, asynchronous process invocation, event wait when the event is already arrived, etc.
        Returns:
        true if the activity instance really needs to be suspended (put in WAITING status).
        Throws:
        ActivityException

      • resume

        boolean resume(InternalEvent eventMessageDoc)
        throws ActivityException
        The method is invoked when the wait activity is resumed. The resume may be a result of receiving external events, either after or before the registration for wait. For MDW 4 style event wait, the secondary owner is always EXTERNAL_EVENT_INSTANCE, so you can access the external message received by calling getExternalEventInstanceDetails(). For MDW 3 style events, the secondary owner is not an external event instance, and the external message is not directly accessible (the main problem we made the change). The method should normally return true, which causes the activity to finish. In case further wait is needed, the activity should register event and return false. When the method returns true, the engine will complete the activity and move on. By default, the transition is determined based on null completion code and FINISH event type. You can change the completion code by using the method this.setReturnCode(). You can also change the event type from FINISH to ABORT, CORRECT and DELAY, by prepending the completion code with "ABORT:", "CORRECT:" and "DELAY:", respectively. Examples are "ABORT:my-return-code" and "CORRECT:".
        Returns:
        true normally, false when the activity need to be put back in waiting status
        Throws:
        ActivityException

      • resumeWaiting

        boolean resumeWaiting(InternalEvent event)
               throws ActivityException
        The method is invoked when the wait activity was put on hold status (due to time out for event wait activities, or receiving non-task events for manual task activities). The method normally should put the activity back to wait status. It also needs to check if the events it is waiting for are already arrived, in which case it should invoke resume() to handle it. The method should return true if there is no need to wait any more (event already arrived and handled), or return false to stay waiting status. The event message in this case does not contain any useful information for resuming waiting, but information there may be needed to construct the parameter calling resume() in case the event is already arrived.
        Throws:
        ActivityException
